title: Mammillaria crucigera tlalocii 3
descriptionHtml:
Overview

This is one of my favorite plants in my collection. While this cactus exhibits the typical features of Mammillaria crucigera subsp. tlalocii, such as a globular form, branching offsets and pups from the main stem, and small white radial spines emerging from orange-tinged areoles, it also displays a few quirks that make it especially delightful to observe up close whenever I water it.

Surface and Spine Irregularities

There’s a noticeable irregularity in the arrangement of tubercles across the midsection of the main stem. They are asymmetrically spaced and interspersed with tufts of wool-like trichomes, forming a band of rough, uneven spination.  

Along the upper edge of this band is a row of tubercles encircling the entire main stem that lack spines altogether, exposing more of the plant’s deep green epidermis than usual. This contrast sharply with the otherwise even, lace-like coverage of white spines originating from orange areoles that typically defines the species. I suspect the absence of spines along this row may be the result of phenotypic variation rather than physical damage. 

Offset Development

I’m especially excited to see how the smaller offsets along the stem continue to develop. When I first received this plant nearly six months ago, the offsets were buds that barely protruded outwards from the surface. Now that they are beginning to take shape, I can start speculating about how they might mature.

I expect the singular offsets along the main stem will develop the symmetrical, tightly packed tubercle patterns typical of mature specimens—similar to the larger offset at the base. However, there’s one double offset with noticeably wider tubercle spacing, and I’m hopeful it will continue to exhibit irregular traits.

-- June 19, 2025

value.title: First Day Home
value.content: Received the plant in the mail today. Slightly dehydrated but otherwise healthy. Let it rest before watering.

value.title: First Watering
value.content: Watered lightly around the base. Keeping it near a sunny window with bright indirect light.

value.title: New Growth
value.content: Noticed a small new shoot! It’s adapting well. Might repot soon.

title: Pseudolithos migiurtinus
descriptionHtml:
Overview

This Pseudolithos migiurtinus is weird little wrinkled wart of a plant and I just love it. As its name suggests (Pseudolithos means "false stone"), it is a dwarf succulent native to Sommalia's rocky arid environments that resembles a small stone or pebble. The leafless stem is knobby and subspherical: the lower half has a cylindrical U-shape while the top rounds out with knobs and wrinkles, which to me resembles a muffin.

Growth pattern

At the top of this plant is a set of 4 rows of symmetrical and hexagonal tubercles extending from the central crown in a cross-like tessallation pattern. In each row, towards the outer "rim" of the tessallation is a bright yellow-green bud that sits in the valley between two large tubercles, which I assume will eventually develop into a flower.

As it grows, wrinkles between the tubercles deepen into intricate, fractal-like patterns. However, the bottom half of the stem stays relatively smooth as it doesn't have the same wrinkling pattern in between the tubercles. Observing this growth pattern over the past ~8 months really has been a treat.

Size

This plant is tiny, measuring at only 17.86mm wide when I received it on October 21 2024, and it has grown only an additional ~4mm over the past 8 months. I didn't measure its height when I first received it, but it has noticeably grown taller, with its height at ~23.16mm above the soil line.

And really, its size really makes this plant charming. Knowing that this plant can grow up to 60mm in width and 80mm in height gets me excited to witness all kinds of quirky characteristics as it grows to ~3 times its current size.

Color

When it arrived, the color of the stem was a vibrant lime green color. Eight months later, the intense lighting from my T5 bulbs has changed its hue to a muted blue-green. The flaking epidermal cells give the stem a nice dusty/ashy appearance.

— July 14, 2025

value.title: All the leaves fell off
value.content: All the leaves fell off, and it looks like the tip of this seedling dried out. I'm going to prune the tip off and see if it can start a new growth point.

value.title: A little over 3 months after germination
